title-group.subtitle: An Uncommon Finding During Aesthetic Breast Surgery

body.p: The sternalis muscle is an uncommon anatomic variant of the chest wall musculature. It was first reported in Anatomes Elenchus Accuratissimus in 1604.1,2 Few reports of this muscle have appeared in the literature, and there is debate about its anatomic origin, insertions, function, and innervations. Reported as an inconstant finding in Netter’s Atlas,3 the sternalis muscle is described as an analogous muscle that develops along with the rectus abdominis muscle but resorbs when chest development occurs during intrauterine life. Over the years, anatomists have coined a number of terms to refer to the sternalis muscle, such as the accessorius ad rectum and the parasternal, pectoris rectus, or praesternalis muscle.4 The sternalis is an accessory muscle that can originate from the upper sternum and the infraclavicular region, which inserts upon the anterior pectoral fascia, the lower ribs, the costal cartilages, the sheath of the rectus abdominis muscle, and the aponeurosis of the abdominal external oblique muscle. An adipose tissue layer can be interposed between the pectoralis major and sternalis muscles. Some anatomists consider the sternalis a rudiment of the panniculus carnosus in humans.5 Existence of the sternalis muscle varies between the sexes and among ethnic groups; it is reported in 2% of Caucasian individuals, in 8% of individuals of African descent, and in 11% of individuals of Asian descent, as Barlow demonstrated in studies on 532 cadavers.5 According to anatomists, prevalence between the sexes is 8.7% in women and 6.4% in men.6 Clinically, symptoms are not associated with the presence of the sternalis muscle. However, its presence on a mammogram can be mistaken for a wide range of benign and malignant anterior thoracic wall and breast lesions.7

The positioning of the sternalis muscle adjacent to the breast is clinically important. It can be reported in breast surgery, during mastectomy,8 or during other breast surgery procedures such as augmentation mammaplasty9 or mammary reductions. We report the case of a 20-year-old man with bilateral gynecomastia. Preoperative mammary echotomography showed a true case of gynecomastia (glandular type) with no abnormal findings. Bilateral mastectomy with liposuction was planned. We bilaterally injected a solution of 500 mL saline with 10 mL lidocaine and epinephrine (1%). Preventive liposuction slightly reduced the volume of the breast, although most of the volume was represented by the gland. We chose an inferior periareolar incision to perform subcutaneous mastectomy. We extended the incision laterally and medially because of the massive volume that was necessary to remove (Figure 1). We first dissected the gland from the subcutaneous tissue by blunt dissection, leaving a 0.5-cm layer above to avoid superficial irregularities, and then dissected the gland from the underlying muscle. During medial dissection, the sternalis muscle became evident (Figures 2 and 3). Mastectomy showed that the muscle appeared to lie over the pectoralis major, approximately 0.5 cm thick, 2 cm wide, and 12 cm long, with an alignment parallel to the sternum. Inferiorly, its fibers strayed in the context of the rectus abdominis muscle. We did not perform superior dissection to clarify the superior origin because the origin point was higher than the area dissected during mastectomy. We reported the same finding bilaterally. We obtained good correction of the deformity, and the sternalis muscle was not perceptible postoperatively (Figure 4).

body.p: Recent reports10,11 indicate that the sternalis muscle, despite numerous descriptions in the literature, is relatively unknown by surgeons. It is known more by anatomists, found during dissections.12 The origin, development during fetal life, and insertion of this muscle are controversial. Many authors have debated its function. It can arguably be a vestigial remnant of a muscle that was lost during evolution and is expressed in some individuals.2 The clinical importance of this muscle is evident in different reports. First, it can interfere with diagnosis of significant thoracic pathologic conditions13: authors describe in a screening using mammographic imaging7 that of 32 000 women, only 4 (0.0125%) had this structure. In these cases, the bulge of the muscle and findings on radiologic imaging raised the concern of a possible malignant lesion. From a plastic surgeon’s point of view, the presence of the sternalis muscle may interfere with submuscular pocket dissection during augmentation mammaplasty when a periareolar or inframammary approach is used; conversely, it can be used to cover the prosthesis at its most medial part.9 Moreover, an inexperienced surgeon might find it difficult to detect the correct plane of dissection. In addition, a more experienced surgeon might be concerned by this anatomic finding, resulting in longer operating time.

We could imagine sternalis muscle possibilities as a local flap in chest or neck reconstructions or as a possibility for reconstructive surgery after mastectomy. The presence of the sternalis muscle is relevant during breast cancer surgery because the pectoral fascia and the entire breast tissue should be included in the specimen during modified radical mastectomy: if the sternalis muscle is proximal to a tumor, it should be included in the specimen. The decision to remove the muscle may be affected by its localization, direct invasion with the tumor, and the presence of breast tissue under the muscle.8 The main concern in the current case was to avoid chest deformity after subcutaneous mastectomy. We succeeded in avoiding this by dissecting the mammary gland, leaving a uniform layer of subcutaneous tissue.

The sternalis muscle is an uncommon finding, unknown by most clinicians. Its importance lies in its effect during mammary screening because it may interfere with radiologic images and have an impact on surgical oncologic decisions. It can complicate pocket dissection during aesthetic mammary augmentation or determine thoracic visible deformities, especially for young surgeons who may not recognize this anatomically rare finding.
